Five undergraduates were formally initiated into Tau Beta Pi
last Thursday, December 11:
George H. Bald,'25; Harry J. Engel, '26; Edward 0. Michel, '25;
T. Harold Sanderson, '25, and
Martin J. Urner, '25. Engel was
the only Junior to receive the
honor, as only the man who ranks
first in the Sophomore year is eligible for election. The initiation
was held in the Chemical Laboratory Building.
Following the ceremonies, the
initiates, together with active and
alumni members of Tau Beta Pi,
adjourned to 'the Johns -Hopkins
Club, where the semi-annual banquet of the association was held.
The principal speaker was Colonel
0. W. Proctor, a graduate Tau
teta Pi from Cornell University
and an officer of the Maryland
Casualty Company, who had as
his subject "The Responsibilities
of the Engineer". Colonel Proctor stressed the human side of engineering, and its importance in a
successful engineering career.

For the first time in many years
the Johns Hopkins Musical Club
will present, in Baltimore, a concert and dance preceding its annual Home Concert at the Maryland Casualty Club House. The
Concert and dance will be held in
the 12th floor ballroom of the Belvedere Hotel, 8.30 to 2 P. M.,
Thursday night.
The Musical Club is staging
this performance as a benefit for
the Bryn Mawr League. A large
turnout is expected as the League
has sent out over one thousand
invitations.
Several Feature Numbers

At the Assembly last Thursday
there was a debate. Sophomores declared: "This is so"; Freshmen
said: "You're all wrong; it is not
so." '1 he affirmative won.
The difference of opinion seemed
to center around the question of
whether or not Baltimore should
have a municipal junior college.
Edward H. Prager was the first
speaker for the affirmative, with
seven minutes as the time limit. Delivering his points in measured sentences, Mr. Prager stated his case.
"Baltimore does need a municipal
junior college," he said, "first, because the present system fails to
satisfy the need of the community
and, second, because a logical remedy for this condition would be a
municipal junior college." He finished proving his statements before
his seven minutes were up. Applause.

With all of the color, pomp, and
splendor characteristic of the affair, the Johns Hopkins Cotillon,
the first of the season, was given
Friday evening at the (Maryland
Casualty Clubhouse. Few dances
in the history of the university
have been so impressive in dignity and brilliance. Long planned
by the Cotillon Club, the first formal affair of the college year, and
the crowning event of the preChristmas season, was presented
with fitting beauty.
Muse and Favors Win Admirat'on
Frcin n n e-th ir ty, when the
lancers began to assemble, to one,
the spacious Maryland Casualty
ballroom was flooded with music
furnished by "Bob" Iula's capable
orchestra. The syncopation of
this Baltimore orchestra won
much applause. Following the
custom adhered to in former
years, attractive favors were presented to the women. The souvenir . which had been obtained
from Balfour, consisted of a litle
silver mirror with the Hopkins
seal engraved on the back.
Typical of the Hopkins cotillons there was an absence of
drunkenness. A pledge was required to the effect that no one
should drink intoxicating liquor
from- noon Friday throughout the
day and night.

John Walker Taylor, versatile
Black and Blue gridman, will lead
the Johns Hopkins football team
through the difficult schedule arranged for it next fall. The well
known quarterback was unanimously elected captain at a banquet
given at the Southern Hotel Friday
night to the Hopkins squad and to
many prep school players.
Taylor's election came as a result
of three years of brilliant playing
that more than once brought spectators to their feet. He succeeds
Tom Magill, retiring chief of the
Hopkins eleven.
Dean Ames Speaks

Dean Ames, addressing the foot-ball enthusiasts, extolled the game.
"Football," he said, "is of great
value to education." Dr. Ray Van
Orman praised the team, and said
that, whereas he considered this
year's aggregation one of the best
that Hopkins has ever produced, it
did not quite measure up to the
record made last year. The Black
and Blue coach, in addressing the
prep school guests, intimated that
he would like to become more "familiar" with them. Other speakers
at the banquet were: George Darley, assistant coach; Captain Tom
Magill, William S. Lilly, athletic
director of •Poly, and Henry.Goddard, athletic director of City College. Dr. Ronald Abercrombie was
toastmaster for the event.
Those players of the City and
Poly elevens who are eligible for
college entry next fall were entertained at the banquet when they

Five undergraduates were formally initiated into Tau Beta Pi
last Thursday, December 11:
George H. Bald,'25; Harry J. Engel, '26; Edward 0. Michel, '25;
T. Harold Sanderson, '25, and
Martin J. Urner, '25. Engel was
the only Junior to receive the
honor, as only the man who ranks
first in the Sophomore year is eligible for election. The initiation
was held in the Chemical Laboratory Building.
Following the ceremonies, the
initiates, together with active and
alumni members of Tau Beta Pi,
adjourned to 'the Johns -Hopkins
Club, where the semi-annual banquet of the association was held.
The principal speaker was Colonel
0. W. Proctor, a graduate Tau
teta Pi from Cornell University
and an officer of the Maryland
Casualty Company, who had as
his subject "The Responsibilities
of the Engineer". Colonel Proctor stressed the human side of engineering, and its importance in a
successful engineering career.

For the first time in many years
the Johns Hopkins Musical Club
will present, in Baltimore, a concert and dance preceding its annual Home Concert at the Maryland Casualty Club House. The
Concert and dance will be held in
the 12th floor ballroom of the Belvedere Hotel, 8.30 to 2 P. M.,
Thursday night.
The Musical Club is staging
this performance as a benefit for
the Bryn Mawr League. A large
turnout is expected as the League
has sent out over one thousand
invitations.
Several Feature Numbers

At the Assembly last Thursday
there was a debate. Sophomores declared: "This is so"; Freshmen
said: "You're all wrong; it is not
so." '1 he affirmative won.
The difference of opinion seemed
to center around the question of
whether or not Baltimore should
have a municipal junior college.
Edward H. Prager was the first
speaker for the affirmative, with
seven minutes as the time limit. Delivering his points in measured sentences, Mr. Prager stated his case.
"Baltimore does need a municipal
junior college," he said, "first, because the present system fails to
satisfy the need of the community
and, second, because a logical remedy for this condition would be a
municipal junior college." He finished proving his statements before
his seven minutes were up. Applause.

With all of the color, pomp, and
splendor characteristic of the affair, the Johns Hopkins Cotillon,
the first of the season, was given
Friday evening at the (Maryland
Casualty Clubhouse. Few dances
in the history of the university
have been so impressive in dignity and brilliance. Long planned
by the Cotillon Club, the first formal affair of the college year, and
the crowning event of the preChristmas season, was presented
with fitting beauty.
Muse and Favors Win Admirat'on
Frcin n n e-th ir ty, when the
lancers began to assemble, to one,
the spacious Maryland Casualty
ballroom was flooded with music
furnished by "Bob" Iula's capable
orchestra. The syncopation of
this Baltimore orchestra won
much applause. Following the
custom adhered to in former
years, attractive favors were presented to the women. The souvenir . which had been obtained
from Balfour, consisted of a litle
silver mirror with the Hopkins
seal engraved on the back.
Typical of the Hopkins cotillons there was an absence of
drunkenness. A pledge was required to the effect that no one
should drink intoxicating liquor
from- noon Friday throughout the
day and night.

John Walker Taylor, versatile
Black and Blue gridman, will lead
the Johns Hopkins football team
through the difficult schedule arranged for it next fall. The well
known quarterback was unanimously elected captain at a banquet
given at the Southern Hotel Friday
night to the Hopkins squad and to
many prep school players.
Taylor's election came as a result
of three years of brilliant playing
that more than once brought spectators to their feet. He succeeds
Tom Magill, retiring chief of the
Hopkins eleven.
Dean Ames Speaks

Dean Ames, addressing the foot-ball enthusiasts, extolled the game.
"Football," he said, "is of great
value to education." Dr. Ray Van
Orman praised the team, and said
that, whereas he considered this
year's aggregation one of the best
that Hopkins has ever produced, it
did not quite measure up to the
record made last year. The Black
and Blue coach, in addressing the
prep school guests, intimated that
he would like to become more "familiar" with them. Other speakers
at the banquet were: George Darley, assistant coach; Captain Tom
Magill, William S. Lilly, athletic
director of •Poly, and Henry.Goddard, athletic director of City College. Dr. Ronald Abercrombie was
toastmaster for the event.
Those players of the City and
Poly elevens who are eligible for
college entry next fall were entertained at the banquet when they
were invited to choose Hopkins as
